choices.text: Development of the cochlea is completed by the 20ᵗʰ week
Development of the pinna is completed by the 20ᵗʰ week
The Eustachian tube develops from the first branchial pouch
Middle ear ossicles attain adult size by 6 years of age

questions.text: All are true about embryology of ear development except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pinna develops from the first and second arches.
  • EAC develops from the first branchial cleft and the eustachian tube from the first branchial pouch.
  • Tragus develops from the first arch, rest of the pinna from the second arch.
  • Malleus and incus develop from the first arch.
  • The middle ear ossicles and cochlea are fully grown at the time of birth.

Timing of development of the ear in the week of gestation:

questions.text: Which structure of the ear develops from all three germ layers?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers.

  • The outer epithelial layer is formed by the ectoderm
  • The inner mucosal layer of the endoderm
  • The middle fibrous layer is formed by the mesoderm.

Explanation of other options:

External auditory canal(Option B): The External auditory canal develops from the ectodermal layer.

Stapes(Option C): The Stapes develops from the endodermal layer.

Vestibular labyrinth(Option D): Forms from the otic placode (ectoderm) and surrounding mesoderm, but does not involve endoderm.

questions.text: A patient suddenly had a bout of cough while the ENT doctor was cleaning the EAC with the cotton-tipped probe. Which nerve stimulation is the cause of this cough?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The auricular branch of the vagus (CN X), also called Arnold's nerve, supplies the posterior wall and floor of the external auditory canal (EAC). Hence, stimulation of this nerve is responsible for the bout of cough and occasional syncopal episodes while cleaning the EAC.

Explanation of other options:

Nerve of Wrisberg(Option B): Nerve of Wrisberg: This is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and provides sensory innervation to the external auditory meatus and tympanic membrane. While it can contribute to ear-related sensations, it is not associated with the ear-cough reflex.

Jacobson’s Nerve(Option C): Jacobson's nerve: Also a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, Jacobson's nerve innervates the middle ear and contributes to the tympanic plexus. It does not play a role in the ear-cough reflex.

Auriculotemporal nerve(Option D): Auriculotemporal nerve: A branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3), it provides sensory innervation to the anterior auricle and external acoustic meatus. It does not participate in the ear-cough reflex.

Key takeaways:

Nerve supply of the External Auditory Canal.

questions.text: Wet newspaper-like appearance in the external auditory canal is a feature of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Otomycosis:

  • It is a fungal infection of the EAC.
  • The most common fungus to causes it is Aspergillus Niger
  • Examination: Wet Newspaper Appearance
  • Treatment: Ear toileting.

Explanation of other options:

Localised Otitis Externa(Option A): Localised otitis externa: This condition involves localised inflammation and infection of the ear canal, often presenting with erythema, swelling, and purulent discharge. It does not typically produce the "wet newspaper" appearance.

Exostosis(Option C): Exostosis: Also known as surfer's ear, exostosis refers to the formation of benign bony growths in the ear canal due to repeated exposure to cold water and wind. It does not involve fungal infection and thus does not present with the characteristic debris seen in otomycosis.

Diffuse Otitis Externa(Option D): Diffuse otitis externa: This condition involves widespread inflammation of the ear canal, often due to bacterial infections. While it may present with discharge and swelling, it does not typically produce the "wet newspaper" appearance associated with fungal infections.

choices.text: It may lead to perforation of the tympanic membrane
It may lead to infection of the external auditory canal.
It may make the wax hard and difficult to remove.

questions.text: While syringing for the earwax, cold water should not be used. What is the appropriate reason for this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Use water at body temperature. In syringing, avoid cold water because it can lead to vertigo due to inner ear stimulation.

Ear occlusion by wax collection:

Some people produce more wax, which leads to EAC occlusion by wax collection. This will lead to conductive hearing loss (30 dB CHL approx.)

  • Treatment is Paradichlorobenzene (wax dissolving drops), use these drops for a few days, and the suction clearance or syringing is done.
  • Syringing direction of water is Posterosuperior.

choices.text: Abnormal collection of cerumen in the outer part of the external auditory canal
Abnormal collection of cerumen in the deeper part of the external auditory canal
Abnormal epithelial migration of the skin of the tympanic membrane
Chronic foul-smelling ear discharge present in the external auditory canal

questions.text: Keratosis obturates is caused due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratosis Obturans:

  • EAC skin sheds off to produce keratin inside EAC.
  • EAC skin migrates outwards, bringing keratin and wax out of EAC.
  • Rarely is this skin migration pattern absent, which will lead to the collection of keratin wax as an expansile mass in the ear; this disease is called Keratosis Obturans.

On otoscopic examination:

The EAC appears widened and filled with a dense, white keratin plug.

In advanced cases, the canal may show signs of erosion due to the pressure exerted by the accumulating keratin.

Patients often present with symptoms such as:

  • Hearing loss
  • Ear fullness or blockage
  • Otalgia (ear pain)
  • Occasional ear discharge

Treatment is a surgery called Canaloplasty.

questions.text: The most common cause of Malignant otitis externa is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pseudomonas is the most common cause of malignant Otitis Externa.

Malignant Otitis Externa:

  • It is an infection of the underlying bone of the EAC.
  • It is also called skull base osteomyelitis.
  • It is a life-threatening infection, therefore called malignant otitis externa.
  • It is seen in elderly diabetic patients (60-70 years) and immunocompromised patients.
  • It is caused by 

Clinical Picture:

Old diabetic patient with severe ear ache, blood-stained Ear discharge, facial paralysis ± 9, 10, 11,12 paralysis via skull base.

Examination by otoscopy:

Inflammation in EAC leads to blood-stained ear discharge.

Investigation:

  • Technetium (technetium) bone scan- for diagnosis*
  • CT scan. (For extent of disease)

Treatment:

  • Drug of Choice is 3rdGen Cephalosporin(+ Aminoglycoside)
  • Assessment of response to treatmentis by Gallium Bone scan, ESR, C-Reactive protein and Clinical Examination.

questions.text: Infection of the CNS spreads to the tympanic cavity(=middle ear) through:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyrtl's fissure connects the middle ear to the middle cranial fossa. Hence, the infection of the CNS spreads to the middle ear through it.

Explanation of other options:

Cochlear aqueduct(Option A): Aqueduct of cochlea connects inner ear to CSF in subarachnoid space of brain(not middle ear)

Vestibular aqueduct(Option B): The Vestibular aqueduct is the bony cover of the Endolymphatic duct

Canal of Huguier(Option C): The  Canal of Huguier is the exit point of the chorda tympani nerve from the middle ear

Explanation:

  • Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure aimed at repairing a perforated eardrum (tympanic membrane) and, in some cases, reconstructing the ossicles (the small bones in the middle ear) to restore hearing function. This surgery is commonly recommended when a perforation does not heal on its own, often due to chronic ear infections or trauma.
  • Anaesthesia: Typically performed under general anaesthesia
  • Surgical Approach: The surgeon may access the eardrum through the ear canal or make an incision behind or in front of the ear, depending on the location and size of the perforation.
  • Graft Material: A graft, often taken from the patient's tissue (such as fascia or cartilage), is used to patch the eardrum.
  • Additional Procedures: If the ossicles are damaged, procedures like ossiculoplasty (reconstruction of the ossicles) or mastoidectomy (removal of infected mastoid bone) may be performed concurrently.

Key Takeaway:

Types of tympanoplasty:

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady, while cleaning her ear with a hairpin pin accidentally damaged her eardrum. The tympanic membrane is shown below. What is the best management in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Treatment of Traumatic Perforation of Tympanic Membrane :

  • Conservative Management → Wait & watch.
  • No Ear drops are used.
  • Just keep the Ear dry.

Explanation of other options:

  • Immediate Myringoplasty(Option A):Surgical intervention is not indicated unless the perforation does not heal spontaneously after several months or if complications arise.
  • Antibiotic ear drops(Option B): Only recommended if there is evidence of infection. Routine use is not necessary for uncomplicated perforations.
  • Modified Radical Mastoidectomy(Option D): This is a more invasive procedure typically reserved for chronic middle ear infections with complications, not for simple traumatic perforations.

Key takeaways:

Other conditions of conservative treatment in ENT:

  1. U/L Vocal cord palsy.
  2. Laryngomalacia
  3. CSF Rhinorrhoea
  4. Traumatic Perforation of TM.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the picture
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given instrument is Siegel's speculum.

Seigelisation means applying air pressure in the external auditory canal using Siegel's speculum. Its uses include:

  • To see the mobility of the tympanic membrane.
  • Assessment of Middle Ear Aeration
  • Magnification of the image
  • Fistula test for labyrinthine fistula
  • To perform Gelle's test

Siegel's speculum cannot be used to remove a foreign body from the EAC, as it will push the foreign body further inside the EAC.

Explanation of other options:

Aural Speculum(Option B): An aural speculum is a funnel-shaped instrument used to examine the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane. It is inserted into the ear canal to provide a clear view for diagnosis and treatment. Aural speculums come in various sizes to accommodate different ear canal dimensions.
Politzer Bag(Option C): A Politzer bag is a rubber bulb used to inflate the middle ear by increasing air pressure in the nasopharynx. This technique, known as Politzerization, is employed to open the Eustachian tube and equalise pressure in the middle ear. It is particularly useful in cases of Eustachian tube dysfunction.Ear Syringing Cannula(Option D): An ear syringing cannula is a device used to flush out debris, wax, or foreign bodies from the external ear canal. It is typically connected to a syringe filled with water or saline solution. The cannula is gently inserted into the ear canal to irrigate and cleanse the area.

choices.text: Always occur as an isolated anomaly
Cochlear implants are used in treatment
May be associated with Pendred syndrome & DiGeorge syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Mondini dysplasia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mondini dysplasia may be seen in Pendred, Waardenburg, branchio-oto-renal, Treacher-Collins and Wildervanck syndromes, along with other anomalies.

Mondini dysplasia:

  • Inner ear malformation
  • Only basal coil is present, or the cochlea is 1.5 turns instead of 2.5 turns..
  • There is an incomplete partition between the scale due to the absence of osseous spiral lamina.
  • The condition is unilateral or bilateral
  • It can be treated by a cochlear implant.

Other hereditary conditions of the Ear:
